articles.headline: The Nightjet: A Big Bet on Train Travelers Who Take It Slow
articles.snippet: While other European rail lines have reduced their overnight train services, Austria’s state-owned system is investing in its own.
articles.abstract: While other European rail lines have reduced their overnight train services, Austria’s state-owned system is investing in its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, as Venice awakened to crisp November sunshine, a group of travelers appeared on the steps of Santa Lucia Station. They stood in awe of the Grand Canal just opposite, rummaging for sunglasses in their bags.

articles.headline: Boeing Taps David Calhoun as C.E.O. to Stem 737 Max Crisis
articles.snippet: Over decades, as an executive at G.E. and Blackstone, Mr. Calhoun has been hailed as an experienced and decisive operator.
articles.abstract: Over decades, as an executive at G.E. and Blackstone, Mr. Calhoun has been hailed as an experienced and decisive operator.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the new chief executive of Boeing, David L. Calhoun will take on one of the most challenging tasks in corporate America: steering the embattled airplane manufacturer out of a crisis that has consumed it for more than a year.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Lawmaker Had Visions of a Christian Alternative Government
articles.snippet: A Washington State legislator was accused of participating in the occupation of a federal wildlife refuge. Behind the scenes, he and right-wing activists were preparing for civil strife.
articles.abstract: A Washington State legislator was accused of participating in the occupation of a federal wildlife refuge. Behind the scenes, he and right-wing activists were preparing for civil strife.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Matt Shea was 34 years old when he ran for the State Legislature in eastern Washington, but he had already established credentials that made him a promising Republican candidate.

articles.headline: Dear C.E.O.: Before You Give to Charity, Look at Your Own Workplace
articles.snippet: Many business leaders commendably donate to charity. But they don’t do enough to support their employees and the less fortunate they work with daily.
articles.abstract: Many business leaders commendably donate to charity. But they don’t do enough to support their employees and the less fortunate they work with daily.
articles.lead_paragraph: Real charity doesn’t come with a tax deduction.

articles.headline: Pentagon Eyes Africa Drawdown as First Step in Global Troop Shift
articles.snippet: The deliberations stem from a push to reduce missions battling distant terrorist groups, and to instead refocus on confronting so-called Great Powers like Russia and China.
articles.abstract: The deliberations stem from a push to reduce missions battling distant terrorist groups, and to instead refocus on confronting so-called Great Powers like Russia and China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper is weighing proposals for a major reduction — or even a complete pullout — of American forces from West Africa as the first phase of reviewing global deployments that could reshuffle thousands of troops around the world, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: China’s Seniors, Looking for Love, Head to the Park
articles.snippet: Increasingly widowed and divorced, a new generation of graying singles are navigating modern romance in a rapidly changing country.
articles.abstract: Increasingly widowed and divorced, a new generation of graying singles are navigating modern romance in a rapidly changing country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Zhao Lin had become accustomed to the single life. But his days and nights were growing lonely, and he decided it was time to find Ms. Right.

articles.headline: Congress Saves Coal Miner Pensions, but What About Others?
articles.snippet: Lawmakers will use taxpayer money to fill a roughly $10 billion hole in the miners’ doomed fund. But more plans face the same problems.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers will use taxpayer money to fill a roughly $10 billion hole in the miners’ doomed fund. But more plans face the same problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $1.4 trillion spending bill passed by Congress last week quietly achieves what a parade of select committees and coordinating councils could not: rescue a dying pension fund that is the lifeblood of nearly 100,000 retired coal miners.

articles.headline: The Town That Lost Its Walmart
articles.snippet: For a small town in Texas, the three-decade presence of the world’s largest retailer was a point of civic pride. Then, 18 months ago, all that changed.
articles.abstract: For a small town in Texas, the three-decade presence of the world’s largest retailer was a point of civic pride. Then, 18 months ago, all that changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDNA, Texas — Early on the morning of June 20, 2018, Joe Hermes got a call from an executive in Walmart’s corporate offices. The caller was breaking some bad news: After 36 years, Walmart was closing its Edna store.

articles.headline: Uber Founder Travis Kalanick Leaves Board, Severing Last Tie
articles.snippet: He has sold more than $2 billion of his Uber shares and on Thursday will complete the sale of his remaining stake in the company.
articles.abstract: He has sold more than $2 billion of his Uber shares and on Thursday will complete the sale of his remaining stake in the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Travis Kalanick, the founder and former chief executive of Uber, has stepped down from the company’s board of directors, severing his last tie with the business.

articles.headline: As Protests Flare in India, Modi Plays a New Position: Defense
articles.snippet: With unrest over a divisive new citizenship law sweeping the country, the prime minister is losing some support, even in his strongholds.
articles.abstract: With unrest over a divisive new citizenship law sweeping the country, the prime minister is losing some support, even in his strongholds.
articles.lead_paragraph: VARANASI, India — Nidhi Tiwari is an upper-caste Hindu. She voted for India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, in the last election. She lives in Mr. Modi’s constituency, Varanasi, a holy Hindu city. She was, up until last week, one of the millions of bricks in his base.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar and Saumya Khandelwal
